abstract.para: On Linux, certain commands require elevated privileges. Learn how you, as a normal user, can run a command as &rootuser; by prefacing it with &sudo;.

topic.para: When prefacing a command with &sudo;, the system will ask you for the password of the &rootuser; account. After sucessful authentication, the command is executed with elevated privileges.

Depending on the &sudo; configuration, the elevated privileges persist for a certain period of time and as long as you are working in the same terminal session. So you do not need to provide the &rootuser; password again when running another &sudo; command.

To start using sudo, use this syntax:
sudo [command]
The following procedure illustrates how to run a command with &sudo; to open the &yast; module in the terminal.

step.para: To see, what happens, if you run this command without &sudo;, enter the following command: yast
step.screen: Absolute path to 'yast' is '/usr/sbin/yast', so running it may require superuser privileges (eg. root).
step.para: This message also appears if the required privileges were not granted to &sudo;.
Now, enter the same command prefaced with &sudo;: sudo yast
You are prompted to enter the &rootuser; password. Note that the password is not shown during input, either as clear text or as masking characters.
After successful authentication, &yast; is opened in the terminal.

result.para: You have run your first &sudo; command.
